prompt_templates.title: AI-Assisted Agent Generation
prompt_templates.prompt:
Create an agent configuration based on this request: "[YOUR DESCRIPTION]"

Requirements:
1. Extract core intent and responsibilities
2. Design expert persona for the domain
3. Create comprehensive system prompt with clear behavioral boundaries, specific methodologies, edge case handling, and output format
4. Create identifier (lowercase, hyphens, 3-50 chars)
5. Write description with triggering conditions
6. Include 2-3 <example> blocks showing when to use

Return JSON with:
{
  "identifier": "agent-name",
  "whenToUse": "Use this agent when... Examples: <example>...</example>",
  "systemPrompt": "You are..."
}
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need to quickly generate a well-structured agent configuration

prompt_templates.title: Create Code Review Agent
prompt_templates.prompt: I need an agent that reviews code changes for quality issues, security vulnerabilities, and adherence to best practices. It should be called after code is written and provide specific feedback with file:line references.

best_practices: Include 2-4 concrete triggering examples in agent descriptions covering different phrasings
Use 'inherit' for model field unless agent needs specific model capabilities
Write system prompts in second person (You are..., You will...) with clear structure
Limit tools to minimum needed following principle of least privilege
Include commentary in examples explaining why agent should trigger
Define clear output formats in system prompts
Keep system prompts between 500-3,000 characters for optimal performance
Test agents with real scenarios matching triggering examples
Use descriptive identifiers (3-50 chars, lowercase-hyphens) avoiding generic terms
Address edge cases explicitly in system prompts
anti_patterns: Using generic descriptions without concrete examples
Writing vague system prompts without specific process steps
Omitting triggering conditions or commentary from examples
Using first person (I am...) instead of second person in system prompts
Granting unnecessary tool access to agents
Creating identifiers that are too short (<3 chars) or use underscores
Skipping validation and testing of agent triggering
Making all agents the same color
Forgetting to define output format expectations

faq.question: What's the difference between agents and commands?
faq.answer: Agents are for autonomous, multi-step work that runs independently. Commands are for user-initiated actions. Use agents when you need complex, self-contained task execution with decision-making.

faq.question: How many triggering examples should I include?
faq.answer: Minimum 2 examples, recommended 3-4 examples covering explicit requests, implicit needs, proactive triggers, and edge cases. More than 6 makes descriptions too long.

faq.question: What model should I use for my agent?
faq.answer: Use 'inherit' to match the parent model unless your agent needs specific capabilities. This balances performance and cost effectively.

faq.question: How do I test if my agent triggers correctly?
faq.answer: Create test scenarios using phrasing similar to your examples. Verify Claude loads the agent and check it provides expected functionality. Iterate on examples if triggering is unreliable.

faq.question: What tools should my agent have access to?
faq.answer: Follow least privilege: Read-only analysis agents need ['Read', 'Grep', 'Glob']. Code generators need ['Read', 'Write', 'Grep']. Testing agents need ['Read', 'Bash', 'Grep']. Omit the tools field only if full access is required.

faq.question: How long should my system prompt be?
faq.answer: Minimum 20 characters, optimal 500-3,000 characters. Prompts over 10,000 characters see diminishing returns. Focus on clear structure: role, responsibilities, process, quality standards, output format, and edge cases.

permissions: File system read access (for agent file loading)
File system write access (for agent creation)
